qas.question: How much of the population identified as mixed race in the 2000s?
What is race sometimes seen as?
Who are descendents of various culturally distinct groups?
What does affect recent identification in many cases?
What are the English people mostly descendants of?
When did the Hispanic Civil Rights Movement occur?
How much of the population identified as multiracial before the 2000s?
What is race not acknowledged as?
What did social movements from before the mid-twentieth century work to achieve?

context: <a3_0>The American people<a3_0/> are mostly multi-ethnic descendants of various <b5_0>culturally distinct immigrant groups<b5_0/>, many of which have now developed nations. Some consider themselves multiracial, while acknowledging race as <a2_0><b8_0>a social construct<b8_0/><a2_0/>. Creolization, assimilation and integration have been continuing processes. <a0_0>The African-American Civil Rights Movement<a0_0/> (<b6_0>1955–1968<b6_0/>) and other social movements since the mid-twentieth century worked to achieve <b9_0>social justice<b9_0/> and equal enforcement of civil rights under the constitution for all ethnicities. In the 2000s, <a1_0><b7_0>less than 5%<b7_0/><a1_0/> of the population identified as multiracial. In many instances, <a4_0>mixed racial ancestry<a4_0/> is so far back in an individual's family history (for instance, before the Civil War or earlier), that it does not affect more recent ethnic and cultural identification.
